Review
Micro/nano-encapsulated phase change materials (PCMs) as emerging materials for the food industry
Elham Alehosseini, Seid Mahdi Jafari∗
Department of Food Materials and Process Design Engineering, Gorgan University of Agricultural Sciences and Natural Resources, Gorgan, Iran
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Phase change materials Encapsulation Thermal energy storage Food packaging
A B S T R A C T
Background: The development of energy saving methods and energy storage materials is an emerging hot topic in various fields including the food industry. Thermal energy storage can be accomplished through formulation and application of phase change materials (PCMs). Micro/nanoencapsulation of PCMs is an efficient method for increasing their thermal conductivity, barricades their feasible interaction with the surrounding matrix, and leaks during the melting operation, which lead to an increase in the thermal efficiency of the system. Scope and approach: In this study, we have tried to present a comprehensive review on types and properties of PCMs, encapsulation techniques of micro/nano PCMs, and applications of PCMs in the food industry and future outlook. Key findings and conclusions: Application of thermal energy storage through formulation and use of PCMs is a feasible solution for storage/release of energy. In order to apply PCMs more efficiently, it is necessary to encapsulate them before their application in the final process/product such as incorporating PCMs into packaging structures and refrigeration equipment because of the solid-liquid phase changes. Moreover, micro/nanoencapsulation methods of PCMs are classified into three categories; i.e., chemical (such as suspension polymerization, emulsion polymerization, mini-emulsion polymerization, in Situ polymerization, interfacial polymerization, etc.), physicochemical (such as coacervation, sol-gel encapsulation, etc.), and physicomechanical (such as spray drying, electrohydrodynamic processes, etc.) techniques. Also, the PCMs-assisted packaging is an innovative field of interest for energy storage/release systems to adequately coat or control temperature sensitive food products in various conditions, and could be applied in smart food packaging or pharmaceutical packaging.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The environmental risks originated from the use of fossil fuel-based energy have increased the need of renewable and clean energy resources (Umair, Zhang, Iqbal, Zhang, & Tang, 2019). Furthermore, thermal energy storage can be defined as a strategy which not only reduces the mismatch between supply and demand, but also saves the excess thermal energy via an appropriate medium in a way that the retained energy may be drawn upon at a later time and generally reused in a process that this could be possible by developing energy storage materials (Wahid et al., 2017; Wu et al., 2018). Many materials can exist in different phases such as the glassy form, and amorphous phase at room temperature, even though their crystalline phase is thermodynamically more stable (Raoux, 2009). Amongst the different thermal energy storage forms including thermo-chemical heat storage, sensible heat storage, and latent heat storage, latent heat storage using phase
change materials (PCMs) is the most competitive form due to their benefits that include large energy storage density, low cost, non-corrosiveness, and chemical stability (de Gracia & Cabeza, 2015; Wu et al., 2018; Zhou, Zhao, & Tian, 2012). PCMs are a group of special substances which may be present at minimum in two various phases (one or more crystalline phases and an amorphous phase), and they may be changed frequently between these two phases. Changing from the amorphous phase into the crystalline phase would happen if the material is heated upper its crystallization temperature Tx for a long sufficient time (Raoux, 2009). Moreover, these types of materials are able to save, storage, and release high quantities of energy when undergoing phase changes (Jamekhorshid, Sadrameli, & Farid, 2014). Changing from the crystalline phase into the amorphous phase is introduced via melting and quenching process of the material (Raoux, 2009). PCMs are well known materials for thermal energy storage. PCMs store 5–14 times more heat per unit volume than sensible (conventional) storage materials, which their temperature rises as they absorb heat, such as rock, masonry, or water (Sharma, Tyagi, Chen, & Buddhi, 2009). However, there are limitations on the use of commercial PCMs such as poor thermal stability, low thermal conductivity, and pressure and volume variations during phase changes (Nazir et al., 2019). Since preservation of many foods at refrigerated conditions and maintenance of low temperatures during storage and transportation is essential to avoid/postpone microbial, physical, and chemical changes, the use of PCMs may help in preventing temperature fluctuations (Singh, Gaikwad, & Lee, 2018). Also, due to the high importance of energy saving in the food industry and its direct effect on the final price of manufactured food products, this review attempts to present a summary of types and properties of PCMs, encapsulation techniques and strategies of micro/nano PCMs, phase change fibers (PCFs), and applications of PCMs in the food industry (including smart food packaging for the control of temperature sensitive food products in various conditions).

sections.heading: 2. Types and properties of PCMs
sections.text:
Generally, PCMs can be classified into solid–liquid, solid–solid, liquid–gas, and solid–gas groups (Pielichowska & Pielichowski, 2014). Solid-liquid PCMs are a unique group of materials which tolerate the solid-liquid phase transformation. When a material changes its phase from a solid state into a liquid, it absorbs energy of its surroundings whereas staying at a constant or approximately constant temperature (Kumar et al., 2011). The energy which has been absorbed by the material causes to raise the internal energy of the constituent molecules or atoms, and enhancing their vibrational state, consequently. Also, solidification is the inverse process of this phenomenon so that the material transfers its stored energy into the surrounding environment (Fleischer, 2015). Generally, solid-liquid PCMs can be classified into three groups of organic, inorganic, and eutectic materials (Giro-Paloma, Martínez, Cabeza, & Fernández, 2016; Milián, Gutiérrez, Grágeda, & Ushak, 2017). Organic PCMs are better explained as paraffinic and nonparaffinic. Thermal and chemical stability, recyclability, non-corrosiveness, and no sub-cooling properties are some of the main benefits of organic PCMs. But the drawbacks of applying them are low values of thermal conductivity, flammability, along with a lower enthalpy for phase change compared with the remaining types of PCMs (Tian, Song, Niu, & Feng, 2013; Wang, Guo, Zhong, Wei, & Liu, 2013). Some commercial paraffin waxes have the phase change temperatures and heat storage capacity range of 18–71 °C, and 155–260 (kJ/kg), respectively, and thermal conductivity is about 0.2 (W/m.K) (Zhang et al., 2018).
Inorganic PCMs can be divided into metals, salts, and salt hydrates. This category of PCMs have a higher phase change enthalpy. However, their negative characteristics are the sub-cooling, corrosion, phase segregation, phase separation, and absence of thermal stability. The salt hydrates have water molecules combined in a definite ratio as part of their crystal. They start to dissolve in their own water crystals when the melting point is reached (Giro-Paloma et al., 2016). Hydrated salts and molten salts seem to be extremely appropriate alternatives as energy storage materials (Liu, Rao, Zhao, Huo, & Li, 2015). Moreover, metals have shown a great thermal conductivity, low vapor pressure, and low specific heat. They are excellent candidates to consider for raising the temperature of phase change (Giro-Paloma et al., 2016). Metals consist of special chemical compounds which have a single chemical combination, and solidify at a lower temperature than other combinations gained from the similar compounds (Su, Darkwa, & Kokogiannakis, 2015). The eutectics consist of two or more chemical compounds that have a high density and thermal conductivity (Su et al., 2015). Solidsolid PCMs hold their bulk solid attributes within certain temperature ranges. They prevent the leakage problems that typically occurs in solid-liquid PCMs and can be mixed with other materials without the necessity for encapsulation (Fallahi, Guldentops, Tao, Granados-Focil, & Van Dessel, 2017). Solid-liquid PCMs usually have higher phase transition enthalpies at lower temperatures when compared with solidsolid PCMs. The polymeric and organometallic solid-solid PCMs have enthalpies between 10 and 205 kJ/kg and phase transition temperatures of 15–65 °C, while the organic solid-solid PCMs have phase transition temperatures between 25 and 190 °C and enthalpies of 15–270 kJ/kg (Fallahi et al., 2017). Solid–gas and liquid–gas PCMs have a higher latent heat of phase transition but it has been reported that their application is limited due to their large pressure and volume changes during phase change process (Su et al., 2015; Wahid et al., 2017). A high level of thermal energy storage capacity is the most important attribute of a material to be applied as a PCM. Table 1 shows the main requirements for a material to be a PCM based on the physical, chemical and economical properties. Selection of appropriate PCMs, considering particular applications, depends on operating temperatures, where heating or cooling periods should be completely matched to the transition temperature of PCMs. The PCMs with a higher latent heat value would be desirable to minimize the physical size of the heat store. Also, high thermal conductivity of PCMs facilitates the charging and discharging process of the energy storage. Moreover, phase stability during the freezing-melting process assists setting heat storage. Also, high density enables selecting a smaller size of storage containers, in particular solid–gas and liquid–gas PCMs. Accordingly, small changes of phase transformation volume and vapor pressure during operation results in reduction of containment issues. Increasing a few degrees in super-cooling, particularly for salt hydrates, interferes with adequate heat extraction from the storage. PCM degradation is generally due to water hydration, chemical decomposition, and/or incompatibility with the construction materials. The compatibility of selected PCMs with the casing and other materials should be considered because PCMs may be damaged by loss of hydrated water, chemical disintegration or inadaptability with materials of construction (Al-Abidi et al., 2012; Giro-Paloma et al., 2016; Kumar et al., 2011; Singh et al., 2018; Veerakumar & Sreekumar, 2016).

sections.heading: 3. Micro/nano PCM encapsulation techniques
sections.text:
The micro/nanoencapsulation is a process which surrounds the micro/nano sized particles of solids, gases or liquids within a shell (wall) in order to protect and isolate them from the environmental conditions (Arpagaus, Collenberg, Rütti, Assadpour, & Jafari, 2018; Jafari, Assadpoor, He, & Bhandari, 2008; Jafari, Fathi, & Mandala, 2015). In order to apply PCMs more efficiently, it is necessary to encapsulate them before their usage in final process/product such as incorporating PCMs into packaging structures and refrigeration equipment because of the solid-liquid phase changes (Jamekhorshid et al., 2014). Besides protecting from leakage in the liquid state when combining PCMs with other materials, encapsulation techniques are necessary to protect PCMs by generating PCM-loaded capsules in order to have a better thermal reliability, controlled thermal energy release, reduction of the corrosion, increase the heat transfer efficiency, heat transfer area, and protection against degradation during heat uptake/ release cycles (Alkan, Sarı, Karaipekli, & Uzun, 2009; Hassan, Shakeel Laghari, & Rashid, 2016; Nazir et al., 2019; Shchukina, Graham, Zheng, & Shchukin, 2018; Zheng et al., 2013). Encapsulated PCMs (EPCMs) obtained from the solidification of PCMs, in addition to the raising of heat transfer efficiency and stability of PCMs, also simplify their application, storage and transport (Ho, Siao, & Yan, 2014). Based on the particle size, EPCMs may be classified into nanoencapsulated PCMs (nano PCMs), microencapsulated PCMs (micro PCMs), and macro encapsulated PCMs (macro PCMs) where particles sizes are in the range of 1–1000 nm, 1–1000 μm, and higher than 1mm, respectively (Hassan et al., 2016; Shchukina et al., 2018). The stability of PCM-loaded capsules is provided by the wall material and the breaking rate reduced with decreasing the particle sizes (Liu et al., 2015).
Applied techniques for encapsulation of PCMs should be controlled to avoid their fracture most probably due to the collision with other capsules. In addition, the shell of capsules must be strong enough to tolerate the stress conditions such as volumetric changes during the phase change operation of PCMs (Salunkhe & Shembekar, 2012). Generally, the core material may be just a solid material or a combination of stabilizers, diluents, active constituents, excipients and release-rate accelerators or retardants (Ma, Sun, Li, & Tang, 2014). It should be noted that appending micro PCMs into fluids may raise the viscosity of fluids. Considering the high specific surface area, suspension stability, small particle size, and lower breakage rate during pumping, nano PCMs are gradually gaining attention compared to micro PCMs (Jamekhorshid et al., 2014). Besides, nano PCMs have several unique attributes such as surface effect, macroscopic quantum tunneling effect, volume effect, etc. which leads them to be continually dispersed within the thermal fluid, ensure their usage in thermal management, and energy storage (Liu et al., 2015).
The core-wall (shell) system is a main issue for the production of micro/nanocapsules; in this structure, the core role is to include the active material, herein the PCM, and the shell task is to preserve the core within it. The content of core materials in the capsules are generally between 20% and 95% (W/W), and the synthetic and natural polymers may be used as wall materials. The shell coating materials
(wall) should be able to make a cohesive, flexible, stable, and pliable thin film around the core material in order to protect them (GiroPaloma et al., 2016). A wide spectrum of formaldehyde derivatives (such as gelatin-formaldehyde and melamine-formaldehyde), phenolic resins, polyurethane, gelatin/gum Arabic, chitosan/gelatin, and agar/ gelatin/gum Arabic have been used as wall materials in PCM micro/ nanoencapsulation processes (Bayés-García et al., 2010; Moghaddam, Mortazavi, & Khayamian, 2015; Zhang et al., 2018). Morphology of micro/mano capsules and their attributes is strongly related to the type of core material and applied encapsulation technique (Giro-Paloma et al., 2016). The most important techniques for production of nano PCMs are emulsion polymerization, mini-emulsion polymerization, in situ polymerization, interfacial polymerization, sol-gel technique, and electrohydrodynamic processes ( Chen, Yu, Zeng, & Zhang, 2012; Liu et al., 2015). Generally, encapsulation techniques of PCMs could be divided into three categories of chemical, physicochemical, and physicomechanical techniques which will be explained in the following sections (Giro-Paloma et al., 2016; Kumar et al., 2011). Table 2 shows some selected studies on encapsulated PCMs fabricated using different chemical (polymerization) methods.

sections.heading: 3.1.1. Suspension polymerization
sections.text: In this technique, PCM droplets are formulated via intense agitation of the mixture and dissolution of stabilizers in aqueous continuous phase (Huang, Zhu, Lin, & Fang, 2018). According to Fig. 1A., polymerization is initiated at a desirable temperature until the process is complete (Sánchez-Silva et al., 2010). The advantages of suspension polymerization are excellent heat control of the reaction and also its cost-effectiveness. While drawbacks of suspension polymerization are the production of particles with big sizes (2–4000 μm), and also resulting in few monomers which are water soluble (Chen & Fang, 2011). Some researchers have investigated the effects of suspension polymerization process parameters (e.g. type of materials, mass ratio of core to wall, and reaction temperature) on the thermal specifications of micro PCMs. For example, Sánchez, Sánchez, Carmona, de Lucas, and Rodríguez (2008) have evaluated the effect of mass ratio of paraffin to styrene, the stirring rate, and the reaction temperature on the thermal specifications of micro PCMs. Their results indicated that a higher stirring rate (900 rpm) and temperature synthesis between 98 °C and 113 °C were adequate parameters for the encapsulation of paraffin. Also, the energy storage capacity of capsules was determined 153.5 J/g (Sánchez et al., 2008). Microcapsules loaded with disodium hydrogen phosphate heptahydrate were produced by J. Huang, Wang, Zhu, and Xiao (2013). They improved the latent heat of melting and average diameter to 150 J/g and 6.8 μm, respectively.

sections.heading: 3.1.2. Dispersion polymerization
sections.text: The schematic explanation of dispersion polymerization process is shown in Fig. 1B. This method is considered a single-step technique in which, important parameters such as stabilizer concentration, monomer, initiator, and the reaction time are controlled to have favorable specifications for the produced PCM particles (Giro-Paloma et al., 2016). The distinct advantage of this technique is individual micro-sized mono disperse polymer particles in a single continuous operation, which could be performed through dispersion polymerization of stearic acid (SA) in a PMMA shell by a UV photo-initiated process. The latent heats of freezing and melting to form-stable SA/PMMA composite PCMs were determined as 95.9 J/g and 92.1 J/g, respectively (Wang, Xia, Feng, & Zhang, 2011). The mono disperse PMMA microspheres have also been produced by applying a methanol/water mixture containing hydrophilic polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) (Kim, Lee, Kim, Lee, & Choe, 2006).

sections.heading: 3.1.3. Emulsion polymerization
sections.text:
This process includes the inclusion of PCMs into an oily system through adding an emulsifier. In the next step, an emulsification process is necessary to make a water/oil emulsion, and produce a crosslinked system. Finally, the washing step is performed to eliminate the additional oil (Fig. 1C). The possibility of applying high molecular weight PCMs is the unique advantage of the emulsion polymerization
technique. Its drawback is applying an additional step to purify polymers from the surfactant (Giro-Paloma et al., 2016; Liu et al., 2015). In this field, the PMMA/heptadecane microcapsules have shown excellent energy storage potential (Sarı, Alkan, & Karaipekli, 2010). Also, n-octacosane (Sarı, Alkan, Karaipekli, & Uzun, 2009), docosane (Alkan et al., 2009), and n-heptadecane (Sarı et al., 2010) have been used as core material with PCMs and PMMA resin as the shell materials. Sari
et al. (2014) produced the micro/nano EPCMs through the special reaction of PMMA monomer around n-nonadecane as the core material. Their results indicated that the produced PCM-loaded capsules had a reasonable thermal conductivity (0.18W/m), and thermal/chemical stability (Sarı, Alkan, Biçer, Altuntaş, & Bilgin, 2014). It is worth nothing that nano PCMs have also been fabricated using this technique, and the crystallizing and melting temperatures of nanocapsules were reported as 54.5 °C and 56.9 °C, respectively (Wang, Zhang, Xia, Zhao, & Yang, 2014). Interestingly, the nano PCMs have been produced through applying alkane, polystyrene (PS) and/or PMMA (Liu et al., 2015). It has been demonstrated that PCM-loaded nanocapsules through the emulsion polymerization exhibit a good thermal energy storage ∼49.8 J/g, and release ∼47.9 J/g (Baek, Lee, & Kim, 2007).

sections.heading: 3.1.4. Mini-emulsion polymerization
sections.text: This technique is the usual procedure for producing nano PCMs at present which is commonly used with styrene-butyl acrylate (SBA), polyurea, PS, PMMA, and styrene (St)-methylmethacrylate copolymer as shell materials. Moreover, alkane derivatives are used as PCM core (Graham, Shchukina, De Castro, & Shchukin, 2016; Liu et al., 2015). Schematic illustration of the mini-emulsion polymerization has been depicted in Fig. 1D. In this technique, polymerization reaction is performed inside tiny droplets which are decentralized while size is hold at nanoscale, under the effect of high shear forces, and normally include the monomers, emulsifier, water, and initiator (Liu et al., 2015). Production of nano PCMs by this technique has some advantages such as inner lower energy, more stability, and comparable with emulsion polymerization (Fonseca, McKenna, & Dube, 2010). Produced spherical nanocapsules with a phase change temperature of 18.4 °C and an average diameter of 100 nm have resulted in an excellent energy storage potential equal to 109.2 J/g (Chen, Chen, Zeng, Fang, & Zhang, 2012). Fang et al. (2014) have shown that applying ultrasonic treatment in this technique increases encapsulation efficiency and heat transfer rate through reducing the particles size. Also, the PS/n-dotriacontane nanocapsules presented a good thermal stability and high latent heat capacity equal to 174.8 J/g (Fang et al., 2014).

sections.heading: 3.1.5. In situ polymerization
sections.text:
Fig. 1.E shows the processing steps to produce encapsulated PCMs by in situ polymerization. Accordingly, a composition of the prepolymer solution is prepared by blending of two different polymers as shell, which is then added in the shape of droplets into the PCM emulsion. Prior to the drying process, micro/nanocapsules are cooled and filtered (Giro-Paloma et al., 2016). The distinct benefit of this method is uniform coating. Also, the organic compounds which are generally polymers such as carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC), urea-formaldehyde resin, poly (allyl methacrylate), PMMA, and melamine-formaldehyde are usually used as shell materials (Liu et al., 2015). Encapsulated PCMs produced by in situ polymerization have been shown optimum capsule morphologies with proper thermal attributes (Thiele, Sant, & Pilon, 2015). It is usually a common step to add compounds (e.g. styrene–maleic acid anhydride copolymers) for increasing the mechanical characteristics of encapsulated PCMs (Boh, Knez, & Staresinic, 2005; Šumiga et al., 2011). There are several studies on the production of micro PCMs by in situ polymerization (Boh & Šumiga, 2008; Li, Liu, Hu, Wang, & Gao, 2013; Song, Li, & Wang, 2013). For instance, Boh and Šumiga (2008) have applied this technique where pre-condensates or monomers are only appended to the aqueous phase of the emulsion (Boh & Šumiga, 2008). In another study, nano PCMs (CMC-modified melamine-formaldehyde (MF) as shell and paraffin as core) have been produced through this technique. It has been reported that the CMC-modified capsules had a mean diameter of about 50 nm with excellent uniformity; optimum phase change enthalpy of the capsules was determined about 83.46 J/g (Hu, Huang, & Zhang, 2014). Nan et al. (2014) have interestingly demonstrated that the addition of aniline as a monomer and polyaniline led to reduce the heat resistance
attributes of final PCMs (Nan et al., 2014).

sections.heading: 3.1.6. Interfacial polymerization
sections.text: In order to prepare micro/nano PCMs by this technique, the core material is firstly emulsified through applying a suitable emulsifier for the formation of the water/oil or oil/water emulsions (Fig. 1F). Then, wall polymer is created onto the surface of the core through polymerization of the monomers, and the capsule is subsequently detached from water or oil phase (Liu et al., 2015). The applied polymers, as wall, are multifunctional monomers which are dissolved in the liquid core substance, and scattered in aqueous phase containing a dispersing agent (Giro-Paloma et al., 2016). The most important co-reactant multifunctional reagents include diacid chlorides, diamines, and isocyanates (Jyothi et al., 2010). The main points of interfacial polymerization technique are distinct attributes in size distribution, high reaction velocity, mechanical resistance, mild reaction, versatility, and degradability (Giro-Paloma et al., 2016; Liu et al., 2015). In contrast, in order to produce nano PCMs, the core has to be injected into the syringe by a capillary tube which needs the setting of a direct current and high voltage. Furthermore, the distance between the liquid level of monomer solution and the needle of the syringe requires to be as near as feasible (Liu et al., 2015). Butyl stearate has been applied as a core material and ethylenediamine (EDA) and toluene-2,4-diisocyanate (TDI) were employed as monomers by Liang, Lingling, Hongbo, and Zhibin (2009). Their results revealed that the particle diameter was 20–35 μm, latent heat of fusion was near 80 J g−1, and the phase change temperature was around 29 °C (Liang et al., 2009). Wei, Li, Liu, and Liu (2013) produced micro PCMs containing polyamide paraffin might be easily dispersed in organic or watery solvents, and subsequently indicated better chemical and/or thermal stability. The latent heat and microencapsulation ratio were determined 121.7 J/g and 87%, respectively (Wei et al., 2013). Park et al. (2014) have produced magnetic-PCM nanocapsules through interfacial polycondensation between EDA and TDI with various concentrations of Fe3O4 nanoparticles. The melting and freezing latent heat of the PCM nanocapsules containing 6.6 wt% Fe3O4 have been determined as 83.28 (J/g) and 87.40 (J/g), respectively (Park et al., 2014).

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Coacervation
sections.text:
There are two separate techniques for coacervation processes; a simple and a complex technique. The mechanism of encapsulated PCM production for both simple and complex techniques is similar, excluding an extra procedure in the phase separation (Giro-Paloma et al., 2016; Jamekhorshid et al., 2014). When speaking of complex coacervation, two oppositely charged polymers are interacted together (Ghasemi, Jafari, Assadpour, & Khomeiri, 2017, 2018); while, a desolvation agent is added in order to separate phases in simple coacervation. Simple coacervation technique is the result of interaction between a dissolved polymer and a low molecular substance (Zhang et al., 2018). As shown in Fig. 2., there are three distinct steps in the complex coacervation process (Giro-Paloma et al., 2016; Su et al., 2015). Accordingly, this process consists of the formation of the liquid producing vehicle, core substance, coating substance, and deposition of the coating steps consecutively. Finally, the coating hardening step is performed (Giro-Paloma et al., 2016). This method may be completed by adding the polymer in two steps to achieve a longer lifetime of microcapsules by obtaining a thicker shell (Giro-Paloma et al., 2016). Moreover, impermeability and compactability of capsules are increased through improving size, where a smaller thickness of the capsule shell, and spherical form through a lower speed of polymer deposition increases impermeability (Giro-Paloma et al., 2016). A good control of the particle size is the advantage of this technique. However, its drawbacks are agglomeration and difficulty in scale-up (Giro-Paloma et al., 2016; Jamekhorshid et al., 2014).
This technique has been applied by many researchers for encapsulation of PCMs (Bayés-García et al., 2010; Konuklu, Unal, & Paksoy, 2014). Microcapsules of natural coco fatty acid mixture were applied as PCMs for thermal energy storage by Özonur, Mazman, Paksoy, and Evliya (2006). They have shown that gum Arabic and gelatin mixture were excellent wall materials for microencapsulating coco fatty acid mixture by coacervation (Özonur et al., 2006). Deveci and Basal (2009) have studied on the preparation of micro PCMs by using a mixture of silk fibroin (SF) and chitosan (CHI); and n-Eicosane was applied as the core material. Their results indicated that the highest microencapsulation yield was achieved at a SF/CHI ratio of 20 in the presence of 1.5% n-Eicosane content, and of 0.9% glutaraldehyde as cross-linking agent (Deveci & Basal, 2009).

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Encapsulation of PCMs through sol-gel process
sections.text:
This technique consists of some steps for production of an oxide network by poly-condensation reactions while a molecular precursor is present in a liquid and the sol is a dispersion of colloidal particles or polymers within a solvent where the particles may be amorphous or crystalline. Moreover, a gel includes a three dimensional continuous network of the sol particles that enclose a liquid phase (Jamekhorshid et al., 2014; Kalyane, 2017). The sol-gel technique has been illustrated in Fig. 3. Accordingly, in the first step, metal alkoxide is mixed with the catalyst, complexing agent, and solvent. Then, a transparent and stable colloidal solution is produced by hydrolysis and condensation chemical reactions. The rest of steps are followed by aging sol, curing, sintering, and drying (Jamekhorshid et al., 2014; Liu et al., 2015; Macwan, Dave, & Chaturvedi, 2011). The advantage of this method is the inorganic shell production with a high thermal conductivity (Giro-Paloma et al., 2016). Sol-gel technique is an appropriate method for production of nano PCMs with silicon dioxide as the shell material and indium and/or palmitic as the core material (Liu et al., 2015).
The stabilized form of paraffin/SiO2 compound PCMs were produced by Li, Fang, and Liu (2010). They have shown that mass amount of paraffin in silicon dioxide came up to 92%, and paraffin/silicon
dioxide composites had a solidifying latent heat, solidifying temperature, melting latent heat, and melting temperature of 59.66 kJ/kg, 57.07 °C, 139.59 kJ/kg, and 58.10 °C, respectively ( Li et al., 2010). Encapsulation of PCMs containing palmitic acid and SiO2 has also been performed at the nano scale by sol-gel encapsulation processing. The results have revealed spherically and uniformly nanoencapsulated PCMs with average diameter sizes of 183.7 and 722.5 nm at pH values of 11 and 12, respectively (Tahan Latibari, Mehrali, Mehrali, Indra Mahlia, & Cornelis Metselaar, 2013). Hong et al. (2011) produced nano PCMs with indium as core, and silica as shell by this technique. They showed that through decreasing super-cooling of indium nanoparticles, heat transfer with nanoparticle suspensions can be improved. The effective specific heat of indium nanoparticles encapsulated in tetraethylorthosilicate and sodium silicate were measured as 3.5 J/g.K and 6.8 J/g.K, respectively (Hong et al., 2011).

sections.heading: 3.2.3. Supercritical CO2-assisted encapsulation
sections.text:
Recently, researchers have applied supercritical CO2-assisted encapsulation technique in the production of polymeric composites since it has non-flammable specifications and low critical temperature values. In addition, it is nontoxic, supposed green method, available, and costeffective (Giro-Paloma et al., 2016). Sub-micrometric particles of

Wu and Yang (2011) have shown that the concentrations of polymer solution, volumetric flow rate ratios, and applied temperatures affect the yield production and particle size diameter (Wu & Yang, 2011). Also, Haldorai, Shim, and Lim (2012) demonstrate that supercritical CO2-assisted technique could be a good alternative instead of the traditional techniques such as in situ polymerization and sol-gel method for encapsulation of PCMs (Haldorai et al., 2012). In contrast with applying effective and green synthetic (i.e. supercritical) methods, the synthesis of polymeric composites needs a large amount of organic solvents which can increase the risk of environmental pollution (Giro-Paloma et al., 2016; Haldorai
et al., 2012).

sections.heading: 3.3.1. Spray drying
sections.text:
Spray drying includes dispersing the PCM material in aqueous coating solutions to achieve the desirable size of microcapsules under spray drying process (Fig. 4). Afterwards, the liquid emulsion is atomized into droplets. Then, water is evaporated in a drying chamber that lets the active materials to be enclosed into a matrix of encapsulating material (Giro-Paloma et al., 2016; Jamekhorshid et al., 2014). The benefits of spray drying method are mentioned as being low cost, high yield production, and partial versatility (Mahdavi, Jafari, Ghorbani, & Assadpoor, 2014; Rajabi, Ghorbani, Jafari, Sadeghi Mahoonak, & Rajabzadeh, 2015). The drawbacks of spray drying process are agglomeration of particles, high temperatures, and remaining uncoated particles (Akhavan Mahdavi, Jafari, Assadpoor, & Dehnad, 2016; Jafari, He, & Bhandari, 2007).
The effect of changing spray drying parameters on the attributes of encapsulated PCMs such as encapsulation efficiency, and energy storage/release capacity have been investigated by some scholars. For instance, Hawlader, Uddin, and Khin (2003) produced micro PCMs of paraffin-wax and gelatin/Acacia through both coacervation and spray drying techniques. The DSC results indicated a similar thermal energy storage/release capacity of nearly 145–240 J/g by applying both
techniques. They showed that the capsules obtained by coacervation technique had a higher heat capacity compared to the spray dried samples (Hawlader et al., 2003). Borreguero et al. (2011) have used spray drying technique to encapsulate the paraffin rubitherm (RT27) in the presence or absence of carbon nanofibers (CNFs) and determined the thermal energy storage capacity of 95.6 and 98.1 J/g, respectively (Borreguero et al., 2011).

sections.heading: 3.3.2. Electrohydrodynamic encapsulation
sections.text:
Electrodynamic atomization is a gentle and one-step physical process that has become a promising process to fabricate nanofibers and nanoparticles, since the process can be carried out from an aqueous solution and at ambient temperatures (Alehosseini, Sarabi-Jamab, Ghorani, & Kadkhodaee, 2019;Rostami, Yousefi, Khezerlou, Aman Mohammadi, & Jafari, 2019). Electrohydrodynamic atomization or electrospraying process is a technique of liquid atomization, in which the solution is pulled towards the surface of collector by applying of electrical forces (Assadpour & Jafari, 2018; Faridi Esfanjani & Jafari, 2016). Solvent evaporation is performed during the flight of biopolymer solution toward the ground electrode (Alehosseini, GómezMascaraque, Ghorani, & López-Rubio, 2019; Ghorani, Alehosseini, & Tucker, 2017). In contrast with electrospraying, fibers can also be formed by electrospinning process (Jafari, 2017a). The distinct difference between these processes is related to the degree of molecular interaction and chain entanglement. A high chain entanglement results in electrospinning process, and lower entanglement leads to micro/nano particle formation during the electrospraying process (Alehosseini, Ghorani, Sarabi-Jamab, & Tucker, 2017). The electrospinning has been considered as a more convenient, versatile (i.e. using PCMs with various melting temperatures), and very simple technique for producing ultrafine fibers (Wu et al., 2018). Nowadays, electrospinning is the only industrial method to produce ultrafine fibers with diameters from a few micrometers to 10 nm (Ghorani et al., 2017). Several kinds of electrospinning setups are used to produce phase change fibers (PCFs) such as uniaxial, coaxial, and multi-fluidic electrospinning as shown in Fig. 5 (Wang et al., 2010; Wu et al., 2018).
Uniaxial electrospinning is the most general method for encapsulation of PCMs most probably due to the very controllable operation conditions and simple process setup. The distinct attribute of electrospun PCMs by coaxial method is the core-sheath structure (Rezaei, Ghani, Askari, Shoushtari, & Malek, 2016; Wu et al., 2018). PCMs may be entirely enclosed within the PCFs through this technique compared with uniaxial electrospinning (Wu et al., 2018). Two or more streams of immiscible fluids are injected through an electrified coaxial needle in coaxial electrospinning (Jafari, 2017b). Multi-fluidic electrospinning is usually more favorable than coaxial electrospinning. In this method, two or more solutions of solid-liquid PCMs are applied as core solutions (Wang et al., 2010). In multi-fluidic, PCFs are produced with various phase transition points. In contrast, this electrospinning process is unstable, operation setup is complex, and PCM amounts within PCFs are low (Wu et al., 2018).
Moghaddam et al. (2015) produced micro PCMs containing n-nonadecane, and calcium alginate through melt coaxial electrospraying technique with 56% encapsulation efficiency, and particle diameters lower than 100 μm (Moghaddam, Mortazavi, & Khayamian, 2015). It was shown that at the optimal process conditions, micro/nanocapsules containing n-nonadecane-loaded calcium alginate formed with approximately spherical shapes by electrospraying process. They reported that the latent heat of microcapsule (ΔH=81.67 J/g) was smaller than that of non-encapsulated n-nonadecane (ΔH=146.3 J/g) (Moghaddam, Mortazavi, & Khaymian, 2015). Dodecane with known heat storage attributes has been encapsulated by electrospinning process within zein electrospun fibers. Pérez-Masiá, López-Rubio, and Lagarón (2013) have shown that heat storage properties could be adjusted by changing the process conditions (Pérez-Masiá et al., 2013). There are some studies that investigated the production of PCFs by
electrospinning technique based on long chain aliphatic hydrocarbons and paraffin waxes (Chalco-Sandoval, Fabra, López-Rubio, & Lagaron, 2016; Zhao et al., 2017), polyethylene glycol (Babapoor, Karimi, & Khorram, 2016), long chain fatty acids, and polyethylene glycol (Golestaneh, Mosallanejad, Karimi, Khorram, & Khashi, 2016; Rezaei et al., 2016). For instance, Rezaei et al. (2016) studied on the production of thermal intelligent polyethylene glycol-loaded cellulose acetate nanofibers using electrospinning process and revealed that the thermal energy storage capacity of core/shell nanofibers after the thermal assay was dramatically higher (41.23 J/g) than initial one (14.77 J/g) (Rezaei et al., 2016).

sections.heading: 3.3.3. Other encapsulation techniques
sections.text: In centrifugal extrusion technique, the core and wall materials flow through an inner tube and an annular tube, respectively. Through vibrates or the head rotations, the core and wall materials emerge from the orifices at the end of the tubes and break up into drops. Finally, spherical drops are solidified using heat or suitable chemical reactions in a bath (Ghosh, 2006; Jamekhorshid et al., 2014). In vibrational nozzle method, a laminar flow via a nozzle with an additional vibration of the nozzle is used to produce capsules (Jamekhorshid et al., 2014; Nazir et al., 2019). There are some studies that investigate the preparation of the form-stable PCM composites by a similar technique, but without vibration (Song, Ma, Tang, Yin, & Wang, 2010; Wang & Meng, 2010). In solvent evaporation technique, a coating polymer solution is prepared via dissolving the coating polymer material in a volatile solvent that is immiscible in liquid manufacturing vehicle. Afterwards, depending on the hydrophilicity or hydrophobicity of the core material, it is dispersed or dissolved in the coating polymer solution, respectively. The mixture is added to the liquid manufacturing vehicle phase with continued agitation till the solvent is partitioned into the aqueous phase and evaporated. The advantage of solvent evaporation is its low cost (Jamekhorshid et al., 2014).

sections.heading: 4. Applications of PCMs in the food industry
sections.text:
Some food products should be marketed and distributed under freezing, chilling or refrigerating conditions, because low temperatures improve the quality and microbial safety of food. In order to extend food products shelf-life and prevent their spoilage, preservation of the cold chain during the distribution and sale period is necessary. PCMs are generally used in both energy management and storage (Fleischer, 2015). For the food industry, PCMs have been generally used for heat storage and transportation systems such as chilling storage sections and heat processing sections along with packaging applications ( Lu & Tassou, 2013; Oró, De Gracia, & Cabeza, 2013; Oro, Miro, Farid, & Cabeza, 2012). In Table 3, different studies on applications of PCMs in the food industry has been summarized.
Devahastin and Pitaksuriyarat (2006) have investigated on the latent heat storage (LHS) using paraffin wax as a PCM to save energy during the drying process of sweet potatoes. They reported that the amount of extractable energy via the LHS was 1920 kJ min kg−1 and the energy savings was 40% once applying an inlet ambient air velocity of 1m s−1 (Devahastin & Pitaksuriyarat, 2006). A comprehensive comparison between two heat pipe prototypes (with PCMs or without them) has also been assessed by Lu et al. (2010). Their results revealed that incorporation of PCMs into the cabinet structure decreased 1.5 °C of food temperature during defrost step, and improved the food temperature distribution ( Lu et al., 2010). Similarly, nano-structured calcium silicate (NCS) containing paraffin as composite PCMs have been used to improve the thermal buffering in food packaging. The NCS-PCM compound showed adequate thermal buffering capacity, and hold the blending temperature of the prototype container at 10 °C for 5 h whereas the outside temperature increased to 23 °C (Johnston, Grindrod, Dodds, & Schimitschek, 2008). Günther, Schmid, Mehling, Hiebler, and Huang (2010) stated that PCM emulsions are better in their heat transfer rates compared to larger PCM modules (Günther et al., 2010). Studies in this area are in progress. Applying PCM packaging for thermal protection of ice cream containers has been studied by Oró et al. (2013), and it was described that the application of PCM-loaded packaging protects the ice cream quality when it is placed in ambient conditions (Oró, De Gracia et al., 2013).

sections.heading: 5. Future outlook
sections.text:
PCMs have an excellent potential in latent heat energy storage. The development of PCMs has attained great advances over the last three decades and they have been used in industrial and domestic applications. Despite the excellent advantages of PCMs, some studies have discovered few challenges which must be considered. For example, although electrospinning technique has been a promising method to improve heat management materials in food packaging, further researches need to be performed to increase the heat storage capacity of the polymeric materials and encapsulation efficiency. Thermophysical characteristics of PCMs are the main factors in predicting the energy storage performance and heat transfer properties that effect their application. So, the experimental characterization and theoretical calculation of the specific heat and thermal conductivity of PCMs during the phase change process is a main point for research. Thermal conductivity of PCMs can be improved through addition of materials with a high thermal conductivity. But, the convective heat transfer properties of solid–liquid PCMs will be hindered through such additions. So, developing procedures which enhances the thermal conductivity while maintaining well convection heat transfer properties is necessary. Because the amount of PCMs within the encapsulation medium is important in terms of thermal storage density of the composites, future research activities on the use of suitable encapsulating techniques is necessary to develop the application of composite PCMs. Also, the primary focus of new researches should be on the development and preparation of novel composite functional PCMs, because they have a dual function. The techniques such as micro/nano encapsulation and polymer matrices are capable of stabilization of PCMs. There are several limitations to apply micro/nano encapsulation of PCMs such as high costs of process and selection of the correct materials. Therefore, it is
necessary to reduce the encapsulation costs, facilitate production methods, and improve PCMs stabilization. For example, development of 3D structured supporting matrices can increase latent energy storage capacity of composites. Also, nanomaterials can be applied to increase the thermal stability and improve the shape-stability by fabricating organic PCM composites. Finally, in order to facilitate the selection of production methods and supporting materials, it is necessary to setup a database for PCMs.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusions
sections.text: The use of energy from renewable resources have been considered as an option to solve the energy crisis. The application of thermal energy storage through formulation and use of PCMs is a feasible solution for storage/release of energy. In this work, a summarized review of specifications of PCMs, their encapsulation techniques, and applications in the food industry were presented. PCMs can be classified into organic, inorganic, and eutectic materials. Moreover, there are several techniques for encapsulation of PCMs such as emulsion polymerization, coacervation, sol-gel encapsulation, spray drying, electrohydrodynamic processes, etc. Some studies have revealed that besides improvements in the thermal storage capacity of the thermal transfer fluids, the thermal conductivity efficiency of the fluids could be increased by adding nano PCMs. Recently, PCFs, as fibrous forms of PCMs, have been considered by researchers. These innovative PCMs are of interest as energy storage/release systems to adequately coat or control temperature sensitive products in various conditions (i.e. refrigeration equipment), and can be applied in smart food/pharmaceutical packaging.
